troops are expected to leave this place on the goth ofthis month, and the town is in a wretched state and filled with robbers. I hope to be able to commence a Burman female School soon after our arrival in Amherst. We both enjoy excellent health at present, and desire nothing so much as as be settled where we may be use- full"

 We learn further, by the Rev. MT. Yates, that in the Church at Calcutta, of which he is pastor, 30 were added in the last year. His place is supplied for the present by two brethren in the ministry from England, occasional labours of the Rev. MT. Boardman who with Mrs. Board- man is still in Calcutta. MT. and Mrs. Hough are also in this city.

 A short time before Mr. Yates left Call cutta, he had the pleasure of seeing the venerable Dr. Carey, who enjoyed un- common health, and who was able to per- form his accustomed labours, and to preach with great acceptance. The college at Serampore was in a prosperous state.

 There are m the city of flCalcutta, in- cluding the church at Fort William, seven protestant churches :; 4 of the English es- tablishment, two of the Baptist denomina- ton, and one of Presbyterians.

 The circulation of the Bible in India, and the increasing means of literary and religious information are operating, though silently, a most wonderful moral renova- ton in that extensive country. The uni form influence of literature and science is, the destruction of idolatry, even where Christian religion is not embraced. One instance not long since in which Hindoo of large property, the owner of an idol temple, removed the abomination from the buildiug-destroying the idol, and de- molishing the ,emple,-The circumstance produced in the vicinity great excite ment. .,.

 The Hindoo College in Calcutta, who'll ly supported by the natives, is indirectly doing much good, by scattering informa- ton. Its number of students is believed to exceed 200 and although the princi- ples of Christianity are not acknowledged l the literature and science which this estab- lishment teaches are favorable to civiliza- ton, and calculated to bring idolatry into the most perfect contempt.-ChristiaR W0tcansdn.

NOTICE.

premature widowhood, and on whose al- tar about thirty victims daily bleed as the proportion of our country to the sacrifice. Until clergymen derive their support from hands not polluted with the ugly smutch'Ss of intemperance, the pulpit will continue to slumber over this most hOrrid and des- plating of all examinations.

 To De continKed.

 ELY of BIfaiO county, ". Y.

 Temperance was an eminent virtue m the character of those heroic men who laId the foundation of our country's greatness. Their examples, like their laws, were Sal- utary. Christianity and knQwledge were the pillars on which they endeavored ts erect the mighty fabric of great empire. These they guarded with veStal care. Without these a Republic cannot long ex- ist, and nothing sooner or more effectually undermines their foundation than intem- perance. Where this foe finds unressted admission into any country, its destruction is approaching rapidly, and intestine divis-, ion or external concussion will scarcely be needed to complete its ruin.

 That untiring watchfulnesS against this enemy of all that is desirable in an individ- ual or community, which characterized the first ages of our country, has gradually re- faxed, till almost every vestage is ettaced, And even the wholesome regulations they enisin, are rendered, by prevailing cus- toms, and public opinion, little more tn an. a dead letter. A comparison between the present and the earlier ages of our coun- try as to the temperance of its inhabitants, affords melancholy contrast. Then the introduction into town of '' whole bar rel of spirits" reused the people and the magistrates. Now the importation of hundreds of cargoes and the domestic dis tillations ofabout million of barrels, ,caus- es no alarm. Twenty years ago there were in this country thirty thousand dis tilleries.* If they have since multiplied in ratio equal to the increase of popula- ton, which supposition is probably short of the fact, there are now at least fifteen hundred thousand of these sources of mis- cry and death. The aggregate quantity of spurious liquors used annually in this country is about forty millions of gallons, one fifth of which is imported.t Such vast consumption of ardent liquors cannot but effect the national health. For they create disease and diminish sensoral pow ert or muscular energy. And children u- sually inherit at least in a measure the mal adies and diseases of their parents. The offspring of feeble and enervated parents do not possess the robust health and cor- porial vigor of those descended from pa- rents who are temperate and healthy. How often do we hear the remark that young persons of the present age are not so ath letic and healthy as their forefathers, 1 be- live the truth of this observation is gener- ally, credited. l have never known any attempt to disprove-it. A gentleman of accurate observation, of excellent sense, institutions, who had enjoyed distinguish ed opportunities for judging, informed the writer that those from country where the | the high duties on distilled spirits nearly 1 prohibited the use of them to vast major ity of its population were capable of per- forming more labour on public work 1 where they were employed; and could longer endure muscular exertion than the Americans associated with them. We are compelled to admit this general fact, how ever humbling it may be to our national pride. If the youth of the present age have as much strength and health and as fair prospect of longevity as their ances- tors, let the fact be shown, and let others with ourselves have the satisfaction of be- lieving it. If otherwise, let the cause which is producing deterioration of the public health be ascertained and removed. That cause is MATHEMATICIAN twelve hundred thousand barrels of ardent spirits be drank every year without inJurlng the nations health It is impossible. Such an unnatual use of inebriating liquors must impair public health as well as public mor- als. Such thoughtless and ruinous pro- fusion must inevitably induce not only a dimunition of national health, but ope- rate on multitudes as remote or proxim- ate cause of premature death. It has been ascertaned from the registers of tho friends, that, as a consequence of their temperance one half of those that are born live at the l age of forty-seven years whereas Dr. Pierce tells us that the general population of London die under the age of three years.'s "The number oflives annually destroyed by this vice in our country is thought to be more than ten thousand, and the number ofpersons who are diseased, distressed and impovished by it to be mores than two hundred thousand" "One half tho male population of the United States are supposed by sound and accurate judges to die from disease induced by spurious liquors and this alarming state of things is increasingly

 That our country appears to be pros- porous is beyond doubt. But many tree a.D. L
ESSAY ON INTERFERENCE.

cions of danger are awakened, he is bound in spell which he cannot resist, his des- tiny is sealed and his ruin begun. Once he was temperate and by letting spirits entirely alone, he might have so remained; but like rock tumbled, from the brow of a mountain, he can easily begin the down. ward progress, but to stop it is not in his power; every thing is destroyed in his fearful descent till at length his immortal soul, which might have been polished stone in the heavenly editice, makes the last, awful, irrevocable plunge. Itren,ble lest such be the fate of my country; lest it has already lapsed so far as to have lost the power of self command, unwilling to be reforIned by others and morally una- ble to reform himself Where is it most needed A temparate man who has been a drunkard is almost a miracle.

 Will our General Government erect a. round us dykes and barriers of defence a. gainst this deluge of liquid fire? That government can in reality do nothing to which the will of the people is opposed and if it could,it lacks the disposition to re- form. Let the crowd of altars*" infamous ly erect to Bacchus in the very temple of our national liberty say, what hope or rath- CT what despair arises to us from that quar- ter.

 Will the State Legislatures stay the rav- ages of this desolating plague Let the steady progress of intemperance in every State of the Union, cerlupting and demor- alizing the people, whose breath the Le- gislatures are, reply. Let executive com munications answer, which rank distilleries en massc among our greatest public bles- sings,tt or recommended repeal of ex- isting taxes with the avowed purpose of holding out inducements for their enlarge ment & mdltiplication.H

 Will the ministers of religion interpose the sacredness of their services between their country and this horrible dissolution? Our hope from them if we look at facts, is. extinguished in darkness. Exertions to stand against this fry flood resembling per- sonal resistance to the burning torrents of Etna and Vesuviis. There appears much hazard with nothing certain but defeat. Their duty and their interest seem to mili-

  compatible with fidelity to God and their country. Bnt since the welfare of this land demands it, let them be clothed with divine panoply and with seli-devotion like the patriotism of the ancient Roman, leap fearlessly into the gulf. This might prove the salvation of their country. It would revive diminished confidence, and if it ex- cited against them the hostility of the bad, it would secure them the friendship of the good. If they could be pursuaded to uni- tedly engage in this service, and infexibly pertinacious with their whole soul combat this heaven detying, crime producing, hell peopling, tyrant, we might hope that such of conflict would terminate in their favor. If they should be faithful the con- dict would of course be obstinate, and num- bers would fall before it, who might con- 'ole themselves with the thought that they were in the act of obedience to great ;aptain, that they were suffering in the ield of Christian duty and fell in defence if their country. Of such union of cler- y we can indulge no hope.-For vast mul- itudes of our citizens are employed in inn orting, distilling, vending and retailing his sonl-destroying article, whose eyes re open to the miseries and crimes it cau- es, who are quite willing to appease their onsciences by extending in hand stain- d with "blood of the poor innocents,

 portion of their accursed gains to the ser ice of that religion which declares drunk- 'rds shall not inherit the Kingdom of God. Hundred of thousands more are so in love with this delicious poison that they would !ismiss a minister who acclaimed against [. Their hostility must of course be a. reused against him who should persevere- lngly use his utmost exertions to keep from them an iudulgece, which, be the conse- 4uence what it may, they are bent to en- joy. A large proportion of our whole eff icient population are thus invincibly att tached to this pernicious bane by thirst of gold or love of pleasure. He must be pos- sessed of a martyrs faith who can step out in defiance of public opinion and pertina- ! ciously resist monster whom no one vet has resisted successfully and who by SO doing will render those his enemies on whom both himself and his family are de- pendent for an adlibitam maintainance. The clergy do not, because they dare not attack this Moloch of power, of pollution. and blood. We indeed act in character like the Priest and the Levite, ,d1 " pass bv

ton, from Calcutta, Capt. Titcomb, 1Ol

 days from Sand Heads, we have the dis ] tressing intelligence of the death of Mrs.

 Judson. The Rev. M. Yates, of English ! Baptist Mission at Calcutta, who came

 passenger in the Mars, is the bearer of

 letters giving this information. He is on

 visit to our shores for the recovery of his

 health much impaired by repeated attacks

 of fever.

 The following is an extract of letter to

 lady in Boston, from Mrs. Wade, now in Rangoon with Mir. Wade, both of the American Mission to BurmAh. RANGooN, Nov. IA, 1926. Wy Uery dear Mrs. S.-Our last letters informed you that we were sailing for Am l herst by way of Rangoon where we arrived on the 9th of this month, after long, and

 in some respects very unpleasant passage. From letter which received from Mrs.

 Jndson just before we left Bengal, we | learned that she was n,nch pleased with

 the new station, and the prospect of

 hene for life. We were unusually cheer- ] ful and happy during our voyage, in the prospect of finding at last little peaceful

 spot, where we might devote our few re-

 maining days more directly to the great object flor which we came to this

 country. But when we reached Rangoon

 almost the first intelligence is ****#"***""

 *****Oh, how shall I tell you my dear

 sister that our dear Mrs. Judson is no

 more !!-that she died in strange place, l far, far, from all those who would have felt 1 it their greatest consolation to have

 watched her sickness. I feel my heart too deeply affected by this dark dispensa-

 ton to dwell upon the irreparable loss we have sustained but your afectionate

 heart will suggest all. The melancholy

 intelligence has been sent to Dr. Judson,

 at Ava: but it is not probable that he will

 be able to return in month. My heart

 bleeds to think what he will suffer. But

 why should I indulge so excessive grief, or

 be unreconciled to the will of God2 Tru- ly her worth demands our tears i: but the great Head of the Church can accomplish his wise designs without the aid of mortals and I we'll know, that though He should call aU his most valuable and devoted ser wants home, yet He will spread his glorious gospel through all the nations of this fallen. world. We very deeply regret that we had not been at Amherst from the time of Dr.. Judson's departure for Ava :; but we followed his advice, in waiting in Bengal until he should visit Amherst the second time. After we received his letter, advis- ing us to proceed to Amherst, we sailed in the first ship, with the exception of one which was not considered safe, and which was indeed lost on her wap to Rangoon. All the particulars we have been able to obtain here, are that our dear Sister was i'll of a slow fever about month, and died on the 24th or 18th of October.

 She received every kind attention from a skilful Physician, and enjoyed the society of two European ladies, one of whom has the care of her little daughter at present. The Physician says, that long before he thought her case at all a. farming, he could not prevail upon her to think she should recover and that she l was constantly talking about death. We expect to proceed to Amherst in few days 1 when | hope to be able to give more par ticulars but we find it so very difficult and ! expensive to get passage, but we intend | to proceed in very small vessel, we fear 1 "AAA AAos M ONAS " PAOeCSt uo uOLA SHC prates, who have been very troublesome l here oflate. But duty appears plain, and l after we have taken every prudent pre- caution for our safety, should we fear that He who has preserved us by what seemed l a miracle, will now forsake us No, my sister, we do not fear, because we know that the great Shepherd of Israel never. siumbers or sleeps, and that our lives are the care of kind, unerring Providence. l We also know, by happy experience, that our Heavenly Father can support and cheer us in great extremities: and if he should by any Providence see fit to call us home.-Oh how will that soul be, when It shall like our departed sister, have ex- changed this " vale of tears'' for the pure ]oys which proceed from the throne of

 Uod and the Lamb. I have been enabled 10 anticipate those joys with particular de- l'gnt since our late affective bereavement;

 end ardently desire that all may be sancti- ned to prepare me for the duties of life.-

 Sister Boardman has, no doubt, informed

 you of the circumstances which prevented

 'heir sailing from Bengal ; and after living

 SO happily with them for ten months, you

 will not be surprised to hear me say that
Death ofNrs. Jmlson in IndiG.

Amos Barnum's Estate. "HE subscribers having been appointed by -l the Hon. Court of Probate for the Dis trict of New Milford, Commissioners on the estate of

 AMOS BARNUM, @ late ofKent, in said District. deceased, repre- sented insolvent, hereby give notice that six months from this 9th day of April, 1897, has been allowed by said court for the creditors of said estate to present and exhibit their claims for allowance; and that they will attend the dwelling house of Russell Judd, in said Kent, on the first Tuesdays ofMay and Octo- Der next, at one o'clock, P. M. on each of said days. All claims rot then presented will be forever debarreda recovery.

 RUSSELL JUDD, CO,nniS-

 JABEZ BEARDSLEY, siOners.

 Kent, April 9, 1897. 45

cions of danger are awakened, he is bound in spell which he cannot resist, his des- tiny is sealed and his ruin begun. Once he was temperate and by letting spirits entirely alone, he might have so remained; but like rock tumbled, from the brow of a mountain, he can easily begin the down. ward progress, but to stop it is not in his power; every thing is destroyed in his fearful descent till at length his immortal soul, which might have been polished stone in the heavenly editice, makes the last, awful, irrevocable plunge. Itren,ble lest such be the fate of my country; lest it has already lapsed so far as to have lost the power of self command, unwilling to be reforIned by others and morally una- ble to reform himself Where is it most needed A temparate man who has been a drunkard is almost a miracle.

 Will our General Government erect a. round us dykes and barriers of defence a. gainst this deluge of liquid fire? That government can in reality do nothing to which the will of the people is opposed and if it could,it lacks the disposition to re- form. Let the crowd of altars*" infamous ly erect to Bacchus in the very temple of our national liberty say, what hope or rath- CT what despair arises to us from that quar- ter.

 Will the State Legislatures stay the rav- ages of this desolating plague Let the steady progress of intemperance in every State of the Union, cerlupting and demor- alizing the people, whose breath the Le- gislatures are, reply. Let executive com munications answer, which rank distilleries en massc among our greatest public bles- sings,tt or recommended repeal of ex- isting taxes with the avowed purpose of holding out inducements for their enlarge ment & mdltiplication.H

 Will the ministers of religion interpose the sacredness of their services between their country and this horrible dissolution? Our hope from them if we look at facts, is. extinguished in darkness. Exertions to stand against this fry flood resembling per- sonal resistance to the burning torrents of Etna and Vesuviis. There appears much hazard with nothing certain but defeat. Their duty and their interest seem to mili-

  compatible with fidelity to God and their country. Bnt since the welfare of this land demands it, let them be clothed with divine panoply and with seli-devotion like the patriotism of the ancient Roman, leap fearlessly into the gulf. This might prove the salvation of their country. It would revive diminished confidence, and if it ex- cited against them the hostility of the bad, it would secure them the friendship of the good. If they could be pursuaded to uni- tedly engage in this service, and infexibly pertinacious with their whole soul combat this heaven detying, crime producing, hell peopling, tyrant, we might hope that such of conflict would terminate in their favor. If they should be faithful the con- dict would of course be obstinate, and num- bers would fall before it, who might con- 'ole themselves with the thought that they were in the act of obedience to great ;aptain, that they were suffering in the ield of Christian duty and fell in defence if their country. Of such union of cler- y we can indulge no hope.-For vast mul- itudes of our citizens are employed in inn orting, distilling, vending and retailing his sonl-destroying article, whose eyes re open to the miseries and crimes it cau- es, who are quite willing to appease their onsciences by extending in hand stain- d with "blood of the poor innocents,

 portion of their accursed gains to the ser ice of that religion which declares drunk- 'rds shall not inherit the Kingdom of God. Hundred of thousands more are so in love with this delicious poison that they would !ismiss a minister who acclaimed against [. Their hostility must of course be a. reused against him who should persevere- lngly use his utmost exertions to keep from them an iudulgece, which, be the conse- 4uence what it may, they are bent to en- joy. A large proportion of our whole eff icient population are thus invincibly att tached to this pernicious bane by thirst of gold or love of pleasure. He must be pos- sessed of a martyrs faith who can step out in defiance of public opinion and pertina- ! ciously resist monster whom no one vet has resisted successfully and who by SO doing will render those his enemies on whom both himself and his family are de- pendent for an adlibitam maintainance. The clergy do not, because they dare not attack this Moloch of power, of pollution. and blood. We indeed act in character like the Priest and the Levite, ,d1 " pass bv

full articles.headline: Death ofNrs. Jmlson in IndiG.
full articles.article:
ton, from Calcutta, Capt. Titcomb, 1Ol

 days from Sand Heads, we have the dis ] tressing intelligence of the death of Mrs.

 Judson. The Rev. M. Yates, of English ! Baptist Mission at Calcutta, who came

 passenger in the Mars, is the bearer of

 letters giving this information. He is on

 visit to our shores for the recovery of his

 health much impaired by repeated attacks

 of fever.

 The following is an extract of letter to

 lady in Boston, from Mrs. Wade, now in Rangoon with Mir. Wade, both of the American Mission to BurmAh. RANGooN, Nov. IA, 1926. Wy Uery dear Mrs. S.-Our last letters informed you that we were sailing for Am l herst by way of Rangoon where we arrived on the 9th of this month, after long, and

 in some respects very unpleasant passage. From letter which received from Mrs.

 Jndson just before we left Bengal, we | learned that she was n,nch pleased with

 the new station, and the prospect of

 hene for life. We were unusually cheer- ] ful and happy during our voyage, in the prospect of finding at last little peaceful

 spot, where we might devote our few re-

 maining days more directly to the great object flor which we came to this

 country. But when we reached Rangoon

 almost the first intelligence is ****#"***""

 *****Oh, how shall I tell you my dear

 sister that our dear Mrs. Judson is no

 more !!-that she died in strange place, l far, far, from all those who would have felt 1 it their greatest consolation to have

 watched her sickness. I feel my heart too deeply affected by this dark dispensa-

 ton to dwell upon the irreparable loss we have sustained but your afectionate

 heart will suggest all. The melancholy

 intelligence has been sent to Dr. Judson,

 at Ava: but it is not probable that he will

 be able to return in month. My heart

 bleeds to think what he will suffer. But

 why should I indulge so excessive grief, or

 be unreconciled to the will of God2 Tru- ly her worth demands our tears i: but the great Head of the Church can accomplish his wise designs without the aid of mortals and I we'll know, that though He should call aU his most valuable and devoted ser wants home, yet He will spread his glorious gospel through all the nations of this fallen. world. We very deeply regret that we had not been at Amherst from the time of Dr.. Judson's departure for Ava :; but we followed his advice, in waiting in Bengal until he should visit Amherst the second time. After we received his letter, advis- ing us to proceed to Amherst, we sailed in the first ship, with the exception of one which was not considered safe, and which was indeed lost on her wap to Rangoon. All the particulars we have been able to obtain here, are that our dear Sister was i'll of a slow fever about month, and died on the 24th or 18th of October.

 She received every kind attention from a skilful Physician, and enjoyed the society of two European ladies, one of whom has the care of her little daughter at present. The Physician says, that long before he thought her case at all a. farming, he could not prevail upon her to think she should recover and that she l was constantly talking about death. We expect to proceed to Amherst in few days 1 when | hope to be able to give more par ticulars but we find it so very difficult and ! expensive to get passage, but we intend | to proceed in very small vessel, we fear 1 "AAA AAos M ONAS " PAOeCSt uo uOLA SHC prates, who have been very troublesome l here oflate. But duty appears plain, and l after we have taken every prudent pre- caution for our safety, should we fear that He who has preserved us by what seemed l a miracle, will now forsake us No, my sister, we do not fear, because we know that the great Shepherd of Israel never. siumbers or sleeps, and that our lives are the care of kind, unerring Providence. l We also know, by happy experience, that our Heavenly Father can support and cheer us in great extremities: and if he should by any Providence see fit to call us home.-Oh how will that soul be, when It shall like our departed sister, have ex- changed this " vale of tears'' for the pure ]oys which proceed from the throne of

 Uod and the Lamb. I have been enabled 10 anticipate those joys with particular de- l'gnt since our late affective bereavement;

 end ardently desire that all may be sancti- ned to prepare me for the duties of life.-

 Sister Boardman has, no doubt, informed

 you of the circumstances which prevented

 'heir sailing from Bengal ; and after living

 SO happily with them for ten months, you

 will not be surprised to hear me say that

full articles.headline: AUCTION SALE.
full articles.article:
A IL the personal property belonging to "A the estate of ENOS GRISWOLD, late of Harwinton, in Litchield Probate Dis trict. deceased, which remains undsposed of on the 9th day of May, 1897, will on that day be sold at public auction, at 2 o'clock P. M. Sale to be at the dwelling house of said deceased, in Harwinton.

 By order cfthe Court cf Probate,

 TRACY PECK, Adnia.

 Bristol, April 19, 1927. 45

full articles.headline: Amos Barnum's Estate.
full articles.article:
Amos Barnum's Estate. "HE subscribers having been appointed by -l the Hon. Court of Probate for the Dis trict of New Milford, Commissioners on the estate of

 AMOS BARNUM, @ late ofKent, in said District. deceased, repre- sented insolvent, hereby give notice that six months from this 9th day of April, 1897, has been allowed by said court for the creditors of said estate to present and exhibit their claims for allowance; and that they will attend the dwelling house of Russell Judd, in said Kent, on the first Tuesdays ofMay and Octo- Der next, at one o'clock, P. M. on each of said days. All claims rot then presented will be forever debarreda recovery.

 RUSSELL JUDD, CO,nniS-

 JABEZ BEARDSLEY, siOners.

 Kent, April 9, 1897. 45

ENROM Ltchfeldto to New York--by Steam

 A Boat John Marshall-through in one day-fare S 1-9--by line stages, to meet the boat at Norwalk-leaving Litchfeld Mon days, Wednesdays and Fridays, at 9 A. M. through Woodbury, Newtown and Bridge port and New-York, Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays. at 7 A. M. for Litchfield, un- til the 1st May-after that at 6 A. M. 6m46
